items.title: City’s 58 Fire Deaths in ’12 Are Lowest on Record
items.abstract: As civilian deaths drop, firefighters continue to be killed or wounded inside burning buildings where no civilians are killed.

items.title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
items.abstract: Morphogenesis, from the Greek words morphê, for shape and genesis, for creation, refers to imitating evolution in developing designs.

items.title: New Site Makes It Easier to View City Spending
items.abstract: The city comptroller’s Web site, to be unveiled Wednesday, makes it easier to analyze and download information on cost overruns and contracts, empowering fiscal watchdogs.

items.title: India’s Capital City Celebrates ‘Design Week’
items.abstract: The best of Indian design, showcased in New Delhi.

items.title: For Migrants, City Life Comes at a High Price
items.abstract: We were willing to overlook the drama in Shi Ayi's life, given how essential she was to the family as a caregiver. But I drew the line at murder.

items.title: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
items.abstract: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.

items.title: Evictions in Walled Old City Stir Up a ‘Hornet’s Nest’
items.abstract: Palestinian residents of the Khaldiyya Ascent are facing eviction threats by Jewish organizations reclaiming properties they owned before Israel was established.

items.title: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
items.abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.

items.title: Review: New York City Ballet’s Winter Season Blends Movement and Music
items.abstract: The company performs “Barber Violin Concerto,” “Fancy Free” and “Who Cares?” under the musical direction of Andrew Litton.

items.title: Buffalo in the City
items.abstract: Once an icon of masculinity, the plaid pattern has become an accidental camp classic.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: David Silva, Manchester City’s Key Piece, Is Now More Valuable Than Ever
items.abstract: As City tries to keep Liverpool in sight in the Premier League standings, it will turn, as it often does, to Silva to drive it forward.

items.title: What if Cities Are No Longer the Land of Opportunity for Low-Skilled Workers?
items.abstract: Dense cities have long promised higher wages, but now that is primarily true for workers with more education, a new analysis finds.

items.title: A Guide to Antigua, Guatemala: A Candy-Colored City Framed by Volcanoes
items.abstract: With its Baroque architecture and thriving textile scene, this former colonial capital is among Central America’s most beguiling destinations.

items.title: Those Iron Scorch Marks Are by Design
items.abstract: Naomi Mishkin, an artist, makes office-appropriate wear with a clever twist.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
items.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.

items.title: Manchester City, Chelsea and Competing With Perfection
items.abstract: Pep Guardiola’s ideas and his teams have changed the way England views the game. The danger is that those changes affect perceptions of what qualifies as success.

items.title: How Remote Work Is Devastating New York City’s Commuter Rails
items.abstract: Before the pandemic, they relied on office workers, who spent up to $500 a month on tickets. At the M.T.A., those sales are down 75 percent.

items.title: Review: At City Ballet, Giving Voice to the Body, With Sneakers
items.abstract: Justin Peck’s “Partita,” set to Caroline Shaw’s Pulitzer-Prize winning composition, opened New York City Ballet’s winter season at Lincoln Center.
